hawaiian_text: A laila, lawe akula ia i kona makuahine e hūnā ma ke ana o Waipouli. A nalo ka makuahine, ho'i maila ia ā ko lākou hale ma Keahumoa, noho ihola. Pi'i a'ela 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o ā luna o kaupoku o ka hale, wehe a'ela i ka mau'u o ke kua a me ke alo, a moe ihola ma waena i luna pono o ke kaupoku.
deepseek-r1-0528-fireworks_translation: Then, he took his mother to conceal in the cave of Waipouli. When his mother was hidden, he returned to their house at Keahumoa and resided there. Nāmakaokapāo'o climbed atop the ridgepole of the house, removed the thatching grass from the back and front, and lay down directly upon the ridgepole itself.
deepseek-r1-0528-fireworks_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>
Then, he took his mother to conceal in the cave of Waipouli. When his mother was hidden, he returned to their house at Keahumoa and resided there. Nāmakaokapāo'o climbed atop the ridgepole of the house, removed the thatching grass from the back and front, and lay down directly upon the ridgepole itself.
</translation>

<commentary>
**Paragraph 11:**
• **Protective Concealment:** Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o relocates his mother, Pō-ka-'ī, to Waipouli for refuge, signifying a critical protective action. Placing her in a cave (ana) serves both practical concealment from Pua-li'i’s threat and spiritual safeguarding, as caves (e.g., lava tubes, sea caverns) held ancestral *ʻiwi kupuna* (bone repositories) and were gateways to *Pō* (darkness, the spirit realm). – Waipouli (dark/dusky waters) in Kapaʻa, Kauaʻi, symbolizes ambiguity and protection (*Kinney 1956:33*). 

• **Domestic-Ritual Reconfiguration:** Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o’s actions upon returning escalate from protection to transformative defiance:
  – **Architectural Mastery:** His ascent to the *kaupoku* (ridgepole) signifies sovereignty over the domestic space. In Hawaiian cosmology, ridgepoles represented the *iwi kuamoʻo* (spinal column) of the house-body, a literal axis between earth (*honua*) and sky (*lani*) (*Handy & Pukui 1958:124*). 
  – **Sacred Dismantling:** Removing *mauʻu* (thatching grass) from *kua* (back/west) and *alo* (front/east) ritually "opens" the house to *ākea* (spacetime expanse), disrupting its protective function. This mirrors ceremonial deconsecration (*hoʻonā*) of structures. 
  – **Liminal Occupation:** Lying "ma waena i luna pono o ke kaupoku" (directly centered upon the ridgepole) embodies mediation: he becomes the physical intermediary between opposing forces – back/front (*kua*/*alo*), earth/sky, temporal/power (*mana*). This foreshadows his transition to a *kupua* (demigod) navigating dual realms. 

• **Allegorical Rupture:** This scene subverts *ʻAi Kapu* norms:
  – Threatening to consume Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o (*Paragraph 6*) inverted sacrificial protocol. Here, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o inverts domestic order: traditionally, *aliʻi* held power through visible stewardship, not deconstruction. His act rejects Pua-liʻi’s violently archaic authority.
  – "Hūnā" (conceal) contrasts with Pua-liʻi’s earlier public threats, emphasizing inversion: the boy’s wisdom protects his mother, while the stepfather’s "canoe-prow" posturing hides (*ka pākuhi*) destructive intent (*Kamakau 1992:85*). 
  – Grass removal signifies vulnerability – a deliberate stripping of *pili* (spiritual binding), enabling exposure to ancestral currents for cosmic realignment. 

• **Onomastic Nuance:** *Waipouli* compounds:
  – *Wai* = fresh water; *pouli* = darkness/night. Its watery darkness mirrors the spiritual ambiguity (*pōuli*) of Pōkaʻī’s hiding. 
  – *Ke-ahu-moa*: *Ke-ahu* = the altar/mound; *moa* = chicken/*red*. As a sacrificial site for *moa* (*Solanum sandwiсense*), the name heightens threat symbolism: Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o reoccupies a site of consumption resistance.
</commentary>
reference_translation: Nāmakaokapāo'o then took his mother to hide her in the cave of Waipouli. When his mother was well hidden, he went back to their house in Keahumoa and stayed there. Nāmakaokapāo'o climbed up onto the roof of the house and took apart the grass thatch of the ridge and the face and laid down on the ridge of the roof.
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
